This email serves as your November 7th, 2025 newsletter for notable professional development and fellowships news at NYU GSAS. Remember you can stay up to date with all upcoming professional development events by subscribing to our Google calendar ! If you have questions about the contents of this newsletter, please contact Abby Williams for Professional Development at gsas.profdev@nyu.edu or Emily Hollenbach for Fellowships & Awards at gsas.fellowships@nyu.edu . Congratulations to our Quad Fellowship Recipient, Nina Harano! Please join us in celebrating GSAS PhD student and fellowship recipient, Nina Harano , who is an awardee of the 2025 Quad Fellowship ! The Quad Fellowship is designed to build ties among the next generation of scientists and technologists and builds on the renewed commitment to regional cooperation. We can’t wait to see what Nina accomplishes in the fellowship year! Born in Tokyo and raised in Okinawa, Nina Harano developed an interest in science through interactions with students at the Okinawa Institute of Science and Technology (OIST) during high school, which inspired her to study abroad. After graduating from Columbia University in the United States with a departmental honor in neuroscience, she is currently pursuing a Ph.D. in Neuroscience at 
the GSAS-affiliated Vilcek Institute of Graduate Biomedical Sciences. Her research in the Sigurdsson Lab focuses on elucidating the molecular mechanisms underlying neurodegenerative diseases, particularly recovery from tau-mediated pathologies. Through her research, she aims to bridge science and society by serving as a bridge between Japan and the United States. Ask a Hiring Manager: What Employers Look for in Candidates Tuesday, November 11th, 1:00-2:00PM Virtual As part of our Ask the Expert Series, get an insider scoop on navigating the job market from a hiring manager who will share what employers look for in candidates. Build your confidence, expand your network, and find answers to your most important career questions through expert advice and interactive activities in a relaxed setting. Register Advocacy and Nonprofit Panel Wednesday, November 12th, 5:30-7:00PM Wasserman USQ Learn about roles in advocacy, policy analysis, and community-based work from NYU alumni discussing their career paths. Stick around for a structured mingling session where you can utilize this time to make introductions, gather insights, and establish your own connections. It’s the perfect atmosphere to chat one-on-one with alumni and industry professionals in a relaxed, supportive space. Register Meet the Industry: Arts Funders Thursday, November 13th, 6:30-8:00PM NYU Production Lab Funding can transform your creative ideas into reality—but where do you begin? Whether you’re developing your first film, launching a new play, or creating an experimental music installation, understanding what funders look for is key. This conversation will illuminate how different organizations support artists, what makes an application stand out, and how seeking funding can become an empowering part of your creative practice rather than an obstacle. Join the NYU Production Lab for an open discussion with representatives from several organizations that fund artists and artistic works. You’ll hear insider perspectives on discovering and supporting new talent, and gain practical insights to help you approach funding with clarity and confidence. Register Grant Writing 101 Tuesday, November 18th, 12:30-2:00PM NYU Changemaker Center This workshop is part of a collaborative series between the Social Impact Career Hub and the Changemaker Center, designed to help students explore purpose-driven career paths and leadership development. This session will introduce strategies to write a successful grant proposal, including program overview, outcomes, budgeting, assessment, and more. The workshop will run for the first hour, and the remainder of the session will be for connecting and building community with peers. Register Mastering the Informational Interview or Coffee Chat (with Employers) Tuesday, November 18th, 5:30-6:30PM Wasserman USQ Join this session and hear from employers as they provide valuable insight into the informational interview. Learn how to initiate coffee chats, conduct conversations, and build connections. Whether you’re interested in networking with recruiters or alumni, this session will equip you with the knowledge needed to embark on your career exploration journey. Register Resources Beyond the Professoriate Beyond the Professoriate is a professional development tool where doctoral students and postdocs can explore your career options , make informed career decisions , 
and learn proven job search strategies . Big Interview Big Interview 's proven, step-by-step system combines expert video lessons and interactive interview practice tools to help students land their dream job. Through this career tool, students will get hands-on practice with mock interviews tailored to their specific industry, job, and experience level. Wasserman Headshot Photo Booth Visit the Headshot Photo Booth at the Wasserman Union Square location anytime the office is open to use the self-service booth. You can even borrow professional clothing from the career closet for your photo! Read more here. LinkedIn Learning NYU provides no-cost access to LinkedIn Learning with thousands of online how-to tutorials taught by real-world professionals covering topics that include technology, business, and creative skills. You'll find tutorials on personal branding, video editing,  Google Sheets, and much more. Focus 2 Career Explore different career options through interactive, online assessments. Reflect on your values, skills, and interests and relate them to possible career paths! Reminder: Use Fellowship Databases! GSAS Fellowships encourages you to view their website . But fellowship databases and guides on our External Resources page can also be helpful! Lafayette Fellowship Benefits: A €1,500 monthly stipend from mid-July 2026 through the end of June 2027 to cover living expenses One year of tuition at a partner French institution for eligible programs Application fee waivers for French academic institutions and master’s programs Student 
visa fee waivers for one academic year A round-trip flight to and from France at the start and end of the program Coverage of travel costs and activities related to the French-American Leadership Program Application Deadline: November 30, 2025 The Lafayette Fellowship is a prestigious new graduate fellowship in France for tomorrow’s leaders. Partnering with 15 of the top French higher education institutions, one year of master’s-level studies are available across science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM); the humanities and social sciences; and the arts, either in French or entirely in 
English. In addition to their academic studies, fellows will take part in the French-American Leadership Program, which explores the future of the transatlantic relationship and provides a 360-degree immersion into European innovation, culture, and policy, as well as access to an international network of mentors. Open to: U.S. citizens Applicants who will be under 27 years of age on July 1, 2026 Possessors of a Bachelor’s degree from a U.S. institution earned between August 2023 and June 
2026 3.7 minimum GPA STEM, humanities, social sciences, and arts students interested in addressing global challenges in a French-American context French proficiency not required Read More Apply Now 2026-27 Language Fellowships from the Blakemore Foundation Benefits: Full tuition and stipend for living, travel, and study expenses Application Deadline: December 30th, 2025 at 11:00 PM PST Blakemore Foundation Asian Language Fellowships are awarded for one academic year for the advanced study of Chinese (in Taiwan), Japanese, Korean, 
Indonesian, Khmer, Thai, or Vietnamese in Asia. Study of Chinese at Tsinghua University in Beijing is also available as a Blakemore Fellowship. Open to: U.S. citizens or permanent residents Graduate students and young/mid-career professionals planning to use referenced language(s) in their career Have completed at minimum the third year of study of the Asian language, and ready to advance to professional fluency Blakemore Kingfisher Art History Language Fellowships are awarded 
for 9-12 months for study of Chinese or Korean in East Asia, who have a well-demonstrated intent to study the pre-twentieth century history of Chinese or Korean art at the doctoral level. Open to: U.S. and Canadian citizens or permanent residents and foreign nationals studying in U.S. or Canadian colleges Interest in pursuing doctoral degree in pre-twentieth century Chinese or Korean art history Have completed at minimum the second year of study of the Asian language in rigorous college-level language programs Read More Apply Now Siddall Sheffield Scholarship Benefits: Full tuition fees for one year Master’s in Engineering program at the University of Sheffield Stipend of £18,000 Application Deadline: January 13, 2026 at 5:00 PM UK time The Siddall Sheffield Scholarship recognizes academic 
excellence, promise of advancement of the Engineering field, and civic engagement in sponsoring prospective Engineering students to study at the University of Sheffield in the UK. Please note you must first apply to the Engineering Masters program to be considered for this award. Open to: US citizen who has formerly studied in the US, is a non-UK resident, and has not lived in the UK Holds a Bachelor degree in a relevant field before UK departure Preferred GPA of 3.7 or higher Join the University of Sheffield Postgraduate online open day on Wednesday 26 November 2025 to learn more about the postgraduate programs available. Read More Apply Now Apply Now for 2026 Summer Internships at RAND The RAND Summer Associate Program introduces outstanding graduate students to RAND, an institution that conducts research on a wide range of domestic and international social policy issues and matters of national security. Summer Associates work at RAND full-time for a 12-week period during the summer and are given the opportunity to conduct research while mentored by an experienced researcher. The program is designed for full-time students who have completed at least two years of graduate work leading to a doctorate (e.g., PhD, EDD, DRPH, SciD, 
etc.) or professional degree (e.g., law or medical degree, professional engineer certificate). Students must be enrolled full-time in a graduate degree program during the spring and fall of 2026 to be considered for the program. Applications are open now and due by December 1, 2025, 11:59 p.m. Pacific Time . Read More New Career Resource: Interstride OGS and the Wasserman Center have teamed up to bring the NYU community a great new resource for international students as well as students looking to work abroad. Interstride is an interactive portal to support your global job search. Access resources for navigating the immigration journey, find jobs from international-student friendly employers, access country guides supporting job searches across the globe, and more! Students can find Interstride at NYUHome .
